entry.title: Using SAP CPI to Perform POST Calls on SAP Datasphere OData API
entry.content:
Hello Everyone,

In my current scenario, I need to perform both GET and POST operations on an OData API exposed from SAP Datasphere. Querying records works fine using OAuth 2.0 with the Authorization Code grant type.

Now, I have another use case where I need to push data from SAP CPI into Datasphere for integration purposes. While I know that data loading can be done using the JDBC adapter in CPI, I would prefer an API-based approach.

The key challenge I’m facing is around executing a POST request to insert records directly into Datasphere tables. Does Datasphere support inserting data into its tables via APIs, or is there a workaround required to achieve this?

If anyone has implemented this in a project, I would really appreciate your insights.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Datasphere not able to connect to Cloud connector
entry.content:
Hi Team, 

We have subscribed Datasphere sub account and trying to add backend systems. While i am trying to add systems getting below error. 

An error occurred while fetching container data.We can provide the following information to assist either you or an SAP engineer to solve the issue:

Correlation ID: c7242ca31c35cf0da69dc8fbcf002ceb
HTTP Status: 500 error
Error Code: connectionbrowse
Technical Message: Failed to fetch the data. Error in getDisConnectionChildren. Failed to get container children for /. Cause 0: request failed: rc=1, msg="Message: Opening connection to backend failed: There is no SAP Cloud Connector (SCC) connected to your subaccount matching the requested tunnel for subaccount \"a6fe4679-3ed9-4211-887e-4da2b8851867\" and SCC location ID, with default value, that is empty string or simply not configured. Check the configuration on SCC and cloud side.\nCode: RFC_COMMUNICATION_FAILURE" Code: 99999

BR,

Naresh.

entry.title: Datasphere: Using Inherited Standard Variables in Derive Value Variables
entry.content:
Hello,

I have an Analytic Model (B) built on top of another Analytic Model (A) with a standard variable for CALWEEK being inherited. In B, I would like to create a Derived Value variable that would map the inherited variable from A as a parameter for the lookup, but it's not available in the list. It's a bit strange to me that this is not allowed. Is it not possible to use inherited standard variables as mappings in other variables?

Regards,

Dimitar

entry.title: SAP Datasphere: SQL or Graphical Views?
entry.content:
Making an Educated Decision

In today’s data-driven world, SAP Datasphere empowers businesses to seamlessly connect, prepare, and manage their data. Among its many capabilities, views play a central role in combining local or remote tables, enriching datasets, and creating meaningful insights.

But when it comes to building these views, SAP Datasphere offers two powerful approaches: Graphical Views and SQL Views.

which one should you choose? Let’s break it down.

1. Understanding Views in SAP Datasphere

Views are essential components that allow you to:

  • Combine data from multiple sources (local or remote tables).
  • Link, filter, and enrich datasets.
  • Rename or remove columns to simplify models.
  • Add calculated columns and custom logic.

This flexibility makes views a cornerstone of data modeling in SAP Datasphere.

2. Understanding Graphical Views

Graphical Views in SAP Datasphere enable you to prepare and model data without requiring any prior knowledge of SQL. Using an intuitive drag-and-drop interface, both business users and non-technical professionals can easily create and manage views.

 

 

With graphical views, you can:

  • Seamlessly add and combine multiple data sources.
  • Join, filter, and enrich your datasets with just a few clicks.
  • Rearrange, rename, or exclude columns to simplify your models.
  • Create calculated columns and perform aggregations effortlessly.
  • Build unions and refine data flows visually.

If necessary, you can generate and display the corresponding SQL statement via the menu path Edit → Export → Preview SQL. This way, graphical views can be used as a template for the SQL views.

3. Understanding SQL Views

SQL Views in SAP Datasphere provide a powerful and flexible way to model data using SQLScript. They are ideal for scenarios that require advanced transformations, complex logic, and fine-grained control over your data.

 

With SQL Views, you can:

  • Gain full control over data transformations and modeling logic.
  • Utilize advanced SQL functions and implement conditional statements.
  • Integrate multiple layers of business rules directly into your data models.
  • Optimize queries and improve system performance.

SQL Views are typically preferred by developers and data engineers, as they offer the depth and flexibility needed for complex scenarios.

Best Use Cases:

  • When your data modeling involves complex transformations that go beyond the capabilities of graphical views.
  • For situations where performance optimization is a top priority.

When you need precise control over every detail of your SQL-based logic.

4. When to Combine Both: Mixed Scenarios

In some cases, the best solution is not choosing between the two but combining them:

  • Use Graphical Views to handle simpler joins and aggregations.
  • Enhance them by embedding SQL logic for advanced calculations.
  • Enrich functions written in SQLScript directly within the graphical interface.

This hybrid approach ensures scalability, flexibility, and performance optimization.

5. Key Differences Between Graphical and SQL Views

  • Graphical Views offer a visual, drag-and-drop interface designed for business users and non-technical teams. They simplify joins, filters, and aggregations without requiring SQL knowledge and are less error-prone.
  • SQL Views provide greater flexibility and advanced customization, ideal for developers and data engineers. With SQLScript, you can handle complex transformations, use subqueries, and apply window functions for optimized data modeling.
  • While Graphical Views are faster for beginners, SQL Views are often quicker, easier to maintain, and reusable for experienced developers.

6. Use Cases and Best Practices

  • For complex, evolving data models that require frequent updates, SQL Views are the better choice. They are easier to read, simpler to maintain, and more scalable over time.
  • If you currently rely on Graphical Views for these scenarios, consider migrating early. Although you can export graphical views to SQL, the generated code is often hard to read and requires manual adjustments.
  • When using SQL Views, follow best practices for readable SQLScript and optimized performance to ensure smooth maintenance.

Conclusion

Choosing between Graphical Views and SQL Views in SAP Datasphere depends on your business needs, team expertise, and data complexity.

  • If you want simplicity and speed, go for Graphical Views.

  • If you need advanced customization and performance control, SQL Views are your best bet.

  • And when in doubt? Mix both approaches to leverage the strengths of each.

By making an educated decision, you can optimize your data modeling process and unlock the full potential of SAP Datasphere.

entry.title: Connecting Datasphere to Salesforce using Generic HTTP connection and API Task
entry.content:
Hi All,

We are trying to connect to Salesforce using the Generic HTTP connection along with the API Task feature. We have confirmed by sending request through Postman that access token is getting generated successfully using the same connection details as configured in the Generic HTTP connection shown in the below screenshot:

But while using the same connection in API Task to connect to Salesforce we are getting "Failed to fetch the access token" error while doing a API Test Run. We are using the following Generic API settings within the API Task:

Would like to know if anything needs to be done differently to make the API Task function as expected.

Regards,

DS

entry.title: SAC Addin with Datasphere Models: Potential problems with table data?
entry.content:
Dear DSP&SAC Addin users,

I've got a - maybe - strange question... but a client of mine hestitates in applying this solution for a time dimension view, where about 20 analytic models are affected (due to association in the underlying fact views).

He claims that on previous changes/updates in the analytic models, several of their Excel reports, created with the SAC Addin (not AO SAC Edition) would be corrupt and could no longer be used.

I tried to find answers here in the community and in SAP for me, but it seems nobody else reported such an issue.

Of course, I can imagine, that if you remove a dimension (or associated attribute view) in the fact view & Analytic model that this is no longer available in the Excel table ... but does this really cause the failure of using it? Would not a "Refresh" of the data source display the remaining table data like before, just without this attribute?

Would also added dimensions or attributes (in fact or AM) have any negative effect on the SAC Addin table in Excel?

Unfortunately I took over support only recently, since the internal colleauge left the company. So, I have no proof for this, so far.

I'm looking forward to your experiences.

BR, Martin

entry.title: SAC Data Analyzer - update data source after changes
entry.content:
Hi Community

I'm facing the issue where I have a saved analysis in SAP Analytics Cloud  data analyzer, and after we've made changes to the analytical data model in SAP Datasphere it does not return any data. Only after resetting the data source does it return data. The problem is that the reset action also resets all the actions that you've performed (selections, filtering, drill etc) in data analyzer. Is there any way to update the data source without loosing all the work you've done?

Thanks

entry.title: Clarification on Time Travel and Data Retention capabilities in SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
Hello SAP Support,

We are currently evaluating data lifecycle and governance features in SAP Datasphere and need clarification on the following points:

Does SAP Datasphere support time travel (i.e., point-in-time queries on data objects similar to historical snapshots in other data platforms)?

If not currently available, is this feature on the roadmap?

entry.title: Extracting SAP S/4HANA Data (Tables & CDS Views) to External Storages
entry.content:
Hey

I’m looking into options for extracting data from SAP S/4HANA (tables and CDS views) into external, non-SAP storages such as AWS S3 / Redshift or Oracle.

So far, I see a few directions, but I couldn’t find a clear statement on SAP’s official strategy for:

  • SAP-native options
  • Third-party tools (how does SAP position ETL tools such as Informatica or Theobald? Are those SAP-certified?)
  • SAP’s current position on BDC? Specifically Datasphere, which could also be used for data replication to an external target database?

Any references (SAP Notes, blogs, architecture guides, or project experience) would be very helpful.

entry.title: Taking and storing snapshots within Datasphere itself
entry.content:
Is there a way to take and store a snapshot of a view within Datasphere?

We have a remote source system upon which we cannot implement real-time replication. We therefore have a schedule to refresh the data periodically.

We then have a series of complex SQL views built on top that produce the models.

We have a requirement to provide a snapshot of the data at 6am each day, which can then be compared to the "live" version on-demand, within the same SAC dashboard.

Is there a way to create an extract from the fact view and store it in a local table based on a task, or another suitable option?
I have searched and came across the following passing comment on learning.sap.com:
"Views transform the data at the moment they are read without storing the result (although storing the view result as a snapshot is possible)", but it doesn't explain how.

entry.title: Datasphere: Reading/Storing User Prompt Input
entry.content:
Hello,

I would like to store a user's prompt selections on an Analytic Model, in a table for later use. I tried doing that via a SQL View without success using both an 'insert' statement directly as well as wrapping the insert in an 'exec', but the system seems to treat them as read-only procedures and throws an error. I understand the security reasons behind that and it makes sense,. What I have noticed, however, is that upon refreshing a view with Input Parameters, the values that are entered at first, remain as default values for the reprompt. This leads me to think that these values are cached somewhere. Does anyone know if there is a system table that stores the current session cache or something like that where I can read the prompt selections from? Or is this entirely cached by the browser?

Regards,

Dimitar

Could you please provide us the documentation?

Best,

Chetan

entry.title: Histroy crashing after model replacement
entry.content:
Hello,

We are having this issue with a history in SAP Analytics Cloud, i will describe it in bullets for better understanding:

  1. We developed a analytic model in sap datasphere in a space called QA
  2. Then we made a history in SAP Analytics Cloud that consumes that analytic model in QA, everything is working correctly.
  3. We made a package of the analytic model in QA and imported it into another space called PRD
  4. Then we try replacing the model of the SAP Analytics Cloud history from the model in the space QA to the new model in the space PRD, but when we do this, we get this error:

    And everything crashes, nothing loads, and the web jus collapse.

  5. We tried making a fresh history with nothing in it and consuming the new model in the space PRD and that works fine

  6.  We tried making a fresh history with nothing in it and consuming the new model in the space QA and then replace it with the PRD model and that worked fine too.

  7. We also try erasing the analytic model in prd and all its pipeline, and then make a fresh package and import it again, but it doesn't work.

Thank in advance for your suggestions.
